Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Story: I stare at my phone, thumb hovering over the call button. My lunch break just started, and the office is unusually quiet—supervisors said we could take our breaks whenever we wanted today. I know I should use this time to clear my head, maybe grab a coffee, but my mind keeps drifting back to the argument I had with Alex last night. We’ve been fighting about money all week, and I promised I’d call during my break to talk things through. As his girlfriend, I want to fix this, to show him I care enough to reach out first. But as a telemarketer, I’m expected to stick to my scheduled break and return on time, ready to hit my call quota. If I call Alex now, I might run over my break, and my supervisor could notice. If I don’t, I’ll spend the rest of the shift distracted, replaying our argument in my head. My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations—resolve things with Alex or keep my work record spotless. I can’t seem to do both.
